Hello Thread,

Some things have indeed been fixed, but I'm still not able to amalgamate.  New crash on 0f6d583417b7233ede66642b0319a7c39ff1b672:

```
In file included from jni/predictor.cc:4:0:
jni/../mxnet_predict-all.cc:54:36: fatal error: src/c_api/c_api_error.cc: No such file or directory
 #include <src/c_api/c_api_error.cc>

compilation terminated.
make: *** [jni_libmxnet_predict.o] Error 1
```

I've attached my `mxnet_predict-all.cc.zip`:

[mxnet_predict-all.cc.zip](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/743561/mxnet_predict-all.cc.zip)

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/4750

I don't know what's the problem...... So good luck!

As pointed out [here](https://github.com/dmlc/MXNet.jl/issues/77) (regarding training to minimize custom loss functions in Julia) the above works, but is rather limited. In particular I have been unable to find a way to log the training and validation error during training. I tried to follow the example [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/vignettes/CallbackFunctionTutorial.Rmd), but doing so runs into the problem identified above (the output of a network with a custom loss, is the loss itself, not a predicted value).

I have two questions:
1) Has anyone got an example of a use of `MakeLoss` which also does logging of the train/validation error during training?

2) Does anyone have an example of using a `mx.io.DataIter` in R? I suspect this may help with the problem above, but I have been unable to get this working, and the docs for `mx.io.arrayiter` in R are very limited.

Any pointers greatly appreciated.
I think this is a good idea.

I see a similar issue at https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/3297. However, the asker did not specify what actually worked for him before closing the issue.
The proposed change will not influence current results. It will fix issues as you proposed.

Hi, why did you close this issue? I'm having a similar one on Windows 10 (I've tried to install this on Windows 7 as well with other errors) and I can't figure out how to solve it. Would appreciate any hints!
Are you running docker on windows? I was running docker-machine on a Mac.

@precedenceguo I'm not sure I understand: is it that this doesn't fix any issues with the example if run verbatim? That's true, but the code as it stands is pretty brittle, why not allow it to work with very similar examples if others wish to train on other datasets that adhere to VOC format? We cite MXNet in [soon to be published research](https://arxiv.org/abs/1610.01983) and we are hoping to make our work as reproducible as easy to reproduce as possible without needing to fork the example.

Thank you for making the example more flexible and robust. What I meant is that this change will not impact any existing results (so we don't need to verify them again) and that this change will fix the issues you mentioned in order to work with other datasets in VOC format.
Oh, I misinterpreted your original comment thinking you were suggesting this change not be merged, sorry about that. I appreciate you taking a look.
I think that your PC is an 32 bits architecure,and you need a 64 bits CPU for MXNetR.

You can fix this by changing CHECK_EQ(a, b) to CHECK(a == b) and simiar with CHECK_NE.

There is another issue with change in Torch. We have a pull request on this but the author disapeared https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/4329

It currently publsh to pypi. You can make it publish to snap also.

The benefit of using snap is you can also install scala and R packages. Could you add that?

Also would be great if there is a gpu enabled option.

and we want to enable USE_MKL2017 for cpu only build
Any developments with this?

Adding a deconvolutional augmentation to the current SSD would help as well: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1701.06659v1 Achieves 80.1 mAP on VOC 2007 test and 33.2 mAP on COCO without sacrificing too much in terms of speed. Simple modification of existing feature extractor and additions of deconvolutional network operations at the end of the architecture should improve the SSD.

**I found the generated `mxnet_predict0.d` is not referenced by the target, `mxnet_predict-all.o`.** So many paths are broken. e.g. `<src/c_api/c_api_error.cc>` is living in the `/nnvm/src/c_api/a_api_error.cc`.

I manually set `CFLAGS += -I${MXNET_ROOT}/ -I${MXNET_ROOT}/mshadow/ -I${MXNET_ROOT}/dmlc-core/include -I${MXNET_ROOT}/nnvm -I${MXNET_ROOT}/nnvm/include -I${MXNET_ROOT}/include -I${OPENBLAS_ROOT} -I${OPENBLAS_ROOT}/include -D__MIN__=$(MIN)` and it could compile more but, it fails in the end, the message is:
```
jni/../mxnet_predict-all.cc:22749:25: error: 'log2f' was not declared in this scope
```

Try to downgrade DiagrammeR:

`install_version("DiagrammeR", version = "0.8.1", repos = "http://cran.us.r-project.org")`

And reinstall mxnetR later.
It looks like this will break the API
Anybody is interested in [Tensor API](https://www.khronos.org/registry/OpenVX/extensions/neural_network/html/dd/dad/group__group__tensor.html)?
You can find the source code of an inital [AMD implementation](https://github.com/GPUOpen-ProfessionalCompute-Libraries/amdovx-core/commit/1f4ab6609591c29404d181bfa6ff7abd4a5386e0) of the standard

I think I've managed the most stuff but there are still some problems with the logging facility:
Method 'stream' could not be resolved	iter_normalize.h	/mxnet/src/io	line 103	Semantic Error

somehow the macro doesn't expand to LOG_"XXX". I think here lies the Problem, but can't figure out what is wrong with that, conceptually it seems legit:

#define LOG(severity) LOG_ ## severity.stream()

is this macro trickery realy needed?
I'm testing a new iterator to allow extensive data augmentation with better speed/api, after that I will try to write multiple symbols to match many variations, including this one.

My concern with the Tensor API(and there are a few of its kind) is that they are ***opaque***, not only is this a standardization of Tensor, but it is also a standardization of graph based dl framework

- It is quite easy to see motivation of such design, it maximize the possibility of some optimizations, however,
    - It means it that manages memory, computation for you
    - Eventually you will see that evolves into a deep learning library of its own
    - It means huge effort for each vendor to implement all the scheduling and optimizations that could be shared across hardwares(via using a standard deep learning framework), this might benefit big vendors who have more resources, and provide higher chance of lock in, but was bad for vendors who cannot catch up.
    - It also means we might loose possibility for imperative execution(if execution have to rely on a graph)

Personally, I think what we really need is separation of these things(Tensor data structure, the computation, memory management, scheduling), adopt unix philosophy, do one module more transparently and interact with others, specifically:
- The memory layout of tensor should be transparent, with some indication of variants and layout when necessary in the operation implementations. 
- Allow the user to pass in the memory, and workspace instead of relying on internal allocator
- Make computation as stateless as possible.
- Allow easy hookup to existing kernels, layers
    - e.g. hook that to Torch's TH Tensor, Caffe's layer and MXNet's TBlob

I think what we are discussing here is not really to support XYZ features, that job of deep learning frameworks, but to come up with a minimum module that can be shared across frameworks. 

As I may quote
"Perfection is achieved not when there is nothing more to add, but when there is nothing left to take away"

seems there is enough interest in this issue. What I may suggest is for some of us to post strawman design   of Tensor structure and possible operators and we can comment from these points, these will help things to move toward a concrete direction. 

I largely agree with @soumith and @Yangqing  on a C language structured minimum tensor object (maybe design preferred compact layout, with optional stride support)

Can we try to unify the data pipeline for faster rnn and ssd?

In tiny-dnn, that it is strongly c++1x features oriented we have also evaluated [array_ref](https://github.com/kokkos/array_ref/tree/master/proposals) proposal but I think many here are not interested in the differents c++ standardization efforts.

try reset all changes beside CHECK_NE(chunk, NULL); to CHECK(chunk != NULL);
@nouiz What is your opinion of the openvx [kernel/node api](https://www.khronos.org/registry/OpenVX/specs/1.0/html/da/d83/group__group__user__kernels.html)?

I don't think it is that interesting since it doesn't have any support for looping or branching.

Also it seems heavily oriented towards image processing.

I think anything that tries to manage memory in an opaque way won't get much adoption.

The challenge of a blas like interface is how to minimize wrapping code. Currently you need to write hundreds of lines of code to call convolution with cudnn. For small ops it's completely not worth it.

A C++ interface using templates can still have a blas like philosophy. That sounds more promising.

This is the [graph formalism](https://www.khronos.org/registry/OpenVX/specs/1.0/html/d0/d84/page_design.html#sub_graphs_rules) and this the neural network extension [overview](https://www.khronos.org/registry/OpenVX/extensions/neural_network/html/index.html). It is still provisional and we could work upstream if we want.

Hello, this happens even for the most simple operator (see the example below).

When I look at the code, I think one would simply have to move the InferType implementation in src/operator/operator_util.cc to the default case in include/mxnet/operator.h. The default case checks that all dtypes are float32, and the (more sensible) code in src/operator/operator_util.cc checks whether all dtypes are the same.
I could submit a fix, but I am simply not sure whether this would break other things elsewhere.

Example:
-----
import os
# MXNET_CPU_WORKER_NTHREADS must be greater than 1 for custom op to work on CPU
os.environ["MXNET_CPU_WORKER_NTHREADS"] = "2"
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np

class IdentOp(mx.operator.CustomOp):
    def forward(self, is_train, req, in_data, out_data, aux):
        self.assign(out_data[0], req[0], in_data[0])

    def backward(self, req, out_grad, in_data, out_data, in_grad, aux):
        self.assign(in_grad[0], req[0], out_grad[0])

@mx.operator.register("ident_op")
class IdentOpProp(mx.operator.CustomOpProp):
    def __init__(self):
        # this is not a loss, need gradient input from preceding layers
        super(IdentOpProp, self).__init__(need_top_grad=True)
    
    def list_arguments(self):
        return ['x']

    def list_outputs(self):
        return ['y']

    # All shapes must be the same
    def infer_shape(self, in_shape):
        csp = in_shape[0]
        return [csp], [csp], []
    
    def create_operator(self, ctx, shapes, dtypes):
        return IdentOp()

x = mx.sym.Variable('x')
y = mx.symbol.Custom(x=x, name='identity', op_type='ident_op')

executor = y.bind(
    ctx=mx.cpu(),
    args={'x': mx.nd.zeros([2, 3], dtype=np.float64)})
----

What will be a minimal MVP for a Tensor in the scope of this issue? Is A Tensor interface the first step of a plan? Will each framework needs to handle conversion from/to this "rosetta stone" Tensor?

So your embedding layer weight is 115M x 100?
There are two ways you can split it: by 115M and split by 100
To split by 100, create 2 embeding layer on 2 gpus each 115M x 50.
To split by, create 2 embedding layer with 57M x 100 each and sort your input, then send higher input to 2nd gpu.

That being said. I think you are much better off putting embedding layer on CPU. Host memory is cheap after all.

You can see example/model-parallel-lstm for illustration

Updating an embedding layer like this is crazy though. I think you should do the embedding manually in data iterator, then set input_needs_grad=True for module, and do sparse update manually by your self.
LGTM
